refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the actual number of input/output arguments in a function call

refsynopsisdiv.title: Syntax
refsynopsisdiv.synopsis: [lhs, rhs] = argn() lhs = argn(1) rhs = argn(2)

listitem.para: Number of expected Left-Hand-Side output arguments assigned at the function call.
Number of Right-Hand-Side input arguments provided in the function call.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function is used inside a function definition. It gives the number of actual inputs arguments (rhs) and output arguments (lhs) passed to the function when the function is called. It is usually used in function definitions to deal with optional arguments.
refsection.warning: Testing the existence of a named input argument with isdef(..,"l") is more robust that with argn(). Please see examples.
refsection.para: When the caller function has either no output argument or only varargout, the (lhs) is set to 0. Otherwise, the number of expected arguments is set.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para: Robust test of the existence of input arguments:
refsection.programlisting: function res = test(a, b, varargin) res = "" if isdef("a","l") res = "a passed." end if isdef("b","l") res = res + " b passed." end if isdef("c","l") res = res + " c passed." end endfunction clc test() test(4.321) test(4.321, %z) test(b=3) test(c=3) test(-1, c=3) test(-1, a=2, c=3) test(b=-1, a=2, c=3)

revision.revremark: The lhs argument is set to zero when the caller function has no output assignement.
